container.heading: Medical Laboratories — Testing for Hereditary and Congenital Disorders in Newborn Infants

para.text: This chapter, together with COMAR 10.52.12, establishes a coordinated Statewide system for the screening of newborn infants in the State for certain hereditary and congenital disorders associated with severe problems of health or development.

This chapter also protects the public health by ensuring that accurate and reliable newborn screening and diagnostic test results are provided to a newborn infant's health care providers by requiring a medical laboratory performing screening tests, diagnostic tests, or both, on newborn infants for hereditary disorders, congenital disorders, or both, to:
Operate under reliable procedures and test methods;
Employ qualified personnel;
Establish and maintain reliable quality control and quality assurance programs; and
Interact effectively with components of the Department's coordinated Statewide Newborn Screening Program to identify newborn infants who may be at risk for a hereditary or congenital disorder.

Identifies standards and requirements for a medical laboratory performing screening tests, diagnostic tests, or both, for hereditary and congenital disorders on blood-spot specimens from newborn infants; and
Addresses the following newborn screening and diagnostic tests:
Screening tests, which are:
First-tier tests; and
Supplemental tests; and
Diagnostic tests, which are:
Second-tier tests; and
Supplemental tests.
In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Abnormal test result" means a first-tier, supplemental, or second-tier test result that:
Falls outside the normal range for the analyte measured; and
Triggers a request for additional testing or is diagnostic for a disorder.
Allele.
"Allele" means any one of a series of two or more different forms of a gene or DNA sequence that can exist at a single locus on a chromosome.
"Allele" includes the gene or DNA sequence for hemoglobin traits and disease states, such as hemoglobin S (HbS) for sickle cell disease.
"Analyte" means the substance or chemical constituent in blood being measured in a screening test used to detect the disorders listed in Regulation .12C of this chapter.
Birthing Facility.
"Birthing facility" means a facility that provides the antepartum, intrapartum, and postpartum management and care of women and their newborn infants.
"Birthing facility" includes a:
Birthing service that is licensed or accredited as a unit of a hospital; and
Freestanding birthing center as defined in COMAR 10.05.02.01B.
Blood-Spot Specimen.

“Blood-spot specimen” means a whole-blood specimen collected from a newborn infant’s heel and applied to the designated area on a blood-spot collection test requisition card for the purpose of performing screening tests.
“Blood-spot specimen” includes:

The first screening blood-spot specimen collected from a newborn infant, usually in the birthing facility or other place where the newborn infant was born, within 48 hours after the newborn infant’s birth;
The second screening blood-spot specimen collected from a newborn infant, usually collected when the newborn infant is between 10 and 14 days of age; and

A blood-spot specimen collected subsequent to a blood-spot specimen specified in §B(5)(b)(i) and (ii) of this regulation as required to meet the medical needs and condition of the newborn infant and any additional specific screening blood-spot specimen collection and screening test requirements of this chapter and COMAR 10.52.12.
"Borderline result" means a screening test result that is at or near the established cut-off level for a particular analyte.
"CLIA" means the federal Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988.
Congenital Disorder.
"Congenital disorder" means a significant structural or functional abnormality of the body that is present at birth.
"Congenital disorder" does not include a condition that results from:
An intrauterine infection; or
A birth injury.
"Council" means the State Advisory Council on Hereditary and Congenital Disorders.
“Courier” means an entity employed by a person to convey a blood-spot specimen from the site of blood-spot specimen collection to the laboratory where the blood-spot specimen will be tested.

"Cut-off level" means a pre-determined, measurable value established for an analyte detected by a screening test, where that value is used to determine when a newborn infant's test result is normal, borderline, or abnormal.
"Department" means the Maryland Department of Health.
"Diagnostic test" means a test that is used to establish or confirm the presence of a:
Specific disease; or
Hereditary or congenital disorder.
“First screening” means a screening performed on the first blood-spot specimen collected from a newborn infant after birth.
“First–tier test” means a blood test performed on a newborn infant’s blood-spot specimen that:
Indicates the probable presence or absence of a hereditary or congenital disorder; or
Identifies a newborn infant who is at increased risk for a hereditary or congenital disorder.
“Follow-Up Unit” means the follow-up component and staff of the Department’s Newborn Screening Program, which carries out the duties set forth in COMAR 10.52.12.12.
Hereditary Disorder.
"Hereditary disorder" means a disorder that:
Is transmissible through the genetic material deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA); or
Arises through the improper processing of information in the genetic material.
"Hereditary disorder" includes:
Hemoglobin disorders;
Metabolic disorders; and
Endocrine disorders.
“Home birth” means the birth of an infant which occurs intentionally outside of a birthing facility.

“Home birth attendant” means a physician who is licensed to practice under Health Occupations Article, Title 14, Annotated Code of Maryland, a nurse midwife who is licensed and certified under Health Occupations Article, Title 8, Annotated Code of Maryland, or a direct-entry midwife who is licensed under Health Occupations Article, Title 8, Subtitle 6C, Annotated Code of Maryland, who is caring for the mother and infant at delivery during a home birth as defined in §B(18) of this regulation.
"Metabolic Disorder" means a disorder caused by a genetic alteration that results in a defect in the function of a specific enzyme, hormone, or protein, which can be detected by:
Direct analysis of the enzyme, hormone, or protein; or
Testing for a substance whose metabolism is altered as a result of the defect.
"Newborn" or "newborn infant" means an infant:
Born in Maryland;
Born on federal property within Maryland;
Born outside of Maryland to parents whose residence is in Maryland;

From whom a blood-spot specimen was collected and submitted to the Department’s public health laboratory for newborn screening by a birthing facility or other health care provider located in Maryland, regardless of the infant’s place of birth;
Who has a screening test requested by the Follow-Up Unit:
For first-tier screening follow-up;
For confirmation of a previous screening test result; or
To assist with a newborn infant's diagnosis, therapy, or follow-up care; or
Who is in Maryland.
Newborn Screening or Screening.
"Newborn screening" or "screening" means one or more first-tier tests.
"Newborn screening" or "screening" includes:
First-tier testing on a first, second, or subsequent blood-spot specimen; and
Supplemental first-tier testing.
Newborn Screening Program.
"Newborn Screening Program" means the Department's screening program for hereditary and congenital disorders, which performs operations and activities necessary to ensure that:
Newborn infants are given the opportunity to be tested;
At risk newborn infants who are tested are identified and located;
Newborn infants are given access to necessary follow-up testing;
Diagnostic tests are available and the diagnosis is made or ruled out; and
Newborn infants diagnosed with a hereditary or congenital disorder are given access to treatment.
"Newborn Screening Program" includes:
The Department's public health laboratory as the sole screening laboratory;
Another state's public health laboratory or a commercial laboratory that may serve the State as a screening laboratory during an emergency under a Departmental mutual aid agreement;
Supplemental and second-tier testing performed by a state public health laboratory or by a permitted commercial or research laboratory;
The Follow-Up Unit; and
The State Advisory Council on Hereditary and Congenital Disorders.
"Normal limit" means a measurable, numerical value or range that is considered not to indicate or establish the presence of a hereditary or congenital disorder.
"Permittee" means a person issued a permit by the Secretary to operate a medical laboratory as defined in COMAR 10.10.01.03B.
"Public health laboratory" means:
The Department's public health laboratory; and

Another state's public health laboratory or a commercial laboratory permitted in Maryland that is approved under a Departmental emergency mutual aid agreement to perform newborn screening tests on Maryland newborns.
Quality Assessment Plan.
"Quality assessment plan" means a planned system of step-by-step activities to ensure that:
Testing is carried out according to the manufacturer's instructions;
Testing results are accurate and reliable;
Testing problems and errors are found and corrected to avoid adverse health outcomes for newborn infants; and
Testing results are reported and communicated in a timely manner as required by this chapter.

"Quality assessment plan" includes the ongoing activities that monitor, review, evaluate, and improve the overall quality of the procedures and processes before, during, and after a test is performed.
"Quality control" has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.10.06.03B.
Screening Test.
"Screening test" means a first-tier test used to detect a hereditary or congenital disorder listed in Regulation .12 of this chapter.
“Screening test” includes a test performed on a:
First screening blood-spot specimen;
Second screening blood-spot specimen; or
Subsequent screening blood-spot specimen.
"Screening test" does not include a:
Diagnostic test; or
Second-tier test.

“Second screening” means a test performed on a routine second blood-spot specimen collected when the newborn infant is between 10 and 14 days old even though the test results from the newborn’s first blood-spot specimen were normal.
Second-Tier Test.
“Second-tier test” means a test performed on a newborn screening blood-spot specimen when a first-tier test provides an abnormal screening test result or a borderline abnormal screening test result.
"Second-tier test" includes a test that:
Establishes or confirms a newborn infant's risk for a hereditary or congenital disorder;
Separates a newborn infant into a lower or higher risk category for a hereditary or congenital disorder; or
Is diagnostic because it confirms the presence of a hereditary or congenital disorder.
"Secretary" means the Secretary of Health or the Secretary's designee.
“Supplemental test” means a test performed on a blood-spot specimen collected from a newborn infant that is:
Used to detect a hereditary or congenital disorder not specified in Regulation .12C of this chapter; or
Not required to be performed by the Department's public health laboratory under this chapter or COMAR 10.52.12.

“Unsatisfactory blood-spot specimen” means a blood-spot specimen that may produce an inaccurate or unreliable test result because the blood-spot specimen exhibits one of the problems of collection as specified in Regulation .21B and C of this chapter.
Eligibility.

Except as set forth in a Departmental mutual aid agreement, the Department's public health laboratory is the sole laboratory that may hold a State permit to perform and that may perform a first-tier newborn screening test on a newborn infant.
A medical laboratory other than the State's public health laboratory may obtain a permit to perform:
A supplemental test;
A second-tier test; or
Supplemental and second-tier tests.
Requirements. Before offering to perform or performing a first-tier, supplemental, or second-tier test on a blood-spot specimen collected from a newborn infant, a person shall:
Obtain and maintain a valid:
Permit issued by the Secretary to operate a medical laboratory; and
CLIA Certificate from the U.S. Health and Human Services' Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services; and
Meet applicable standards and requirements for:
A medical laboratory, as set forth in COMAR 10.10.01—.08; and
Testing for hereditary or congenital disorders in a newborn infant as set forth in this chapter.

Inspection Authority. The Department may conduct on-site inspections of a permittee or applicant for a permit to perform supplemental or second-tier tests to screen for or diagnose congenital and hereditary disorders in newborn infants.
Inspection Types. The Department may conduct the following types of inspections to assess compliance with the requirements of this subtitle and COMAR 10.52.12:
An initial inspection before issuing a permit;
A routine inspection during the permit period; and
An inspection subsequent to a complaint.

Permit Fees. A permittee or applicant for a permit that is not exempt under COMAR 10.10.04.01C, or that is not another state's public health laboratory approved to provide newborn screening tests under a Departmental mutual aid agreement, shall pay to the Department the applicable fees as required by COMAR 10.10.04 and this regulation.

Screening and Follow-up Fee Requirement. A birthing center or person responsible for having newborn screening carried out for a newborn infant born outside a birthing facility shall pay a fee of $163.74 per newborn infant to the Department.

Screening and Follow-Up Fee Payment. A birthing center or person responsible for having newborn screening carried out for a newborn infant born outside a birthing facility shall pay to the Department the total fees owed:
On a quarterly basis; and
Within 30 days of receiving an invoice from the Department.
Director Requirement. A permittee that offers to perform or performs a first-tier, supplemental, or second-tier test shall employ a director.
Director Qualifications. The director shall:
Meet the qualifications for a medical laboratory director set forth at COMAR 10.10.07.04; and
Possess a current license as a laboratory director issued by the state in which the laboratory is located if:
The laboratory is not located in Maryland; and
Licensing is required by the state in which the laboratory is located.
Director Responsibilities. The director is responsible for:
The overall operation and administration of the laboratory, including the employment of a sufficient number of competent personnel;

Ensuring that each first-tier, supplemental, or second-tier test conducted is performed accurately and reliably in all aspects of the testing process, including the preanalytic, analytic, and post-analytic phases of the total testing process; and
Ensuring compliance with:
This chapter;
The applicable parts of COMAR 10.10.01— 10.10.08; and

section.heading: Technical Supervisor Requirement, Qualifications, and Responsibilities.

para.text: Technical Supervisor Requirement. A permittee that offers to perform or performs a first-tier, supplemental, or second-tier test shall employ a technical supervisor.
Director as Technical Supervisor. The director may function as the technical supervisor if the director meets the technical supervisor qualifications specified in this regulation.
Technical Supervisor Qualifications. The technical supervisor shall meet the qualifications for a technical supervisor set forth at COMAR 10.10.07.05A(1) and B(7).
Technical Supervisor Responsibilities. A technical supervisor shall be:
Responsible for the:
Technical and scientific methods used in the laboratory; and
Oversight of the laboratory;
Available to the laboratory personnel on an as-needed basis to provide supervision as specified in this chapter; and
Accessible to the laboratory to provide on-site, telephonic, or electronic consultation to laboratory personnel and clients.

section.heading: Clinical Consultant Requirement, Qualifications, and Responsibilities.

para.text: Clinical Consultant Requirement. A permittee that offers to perform or performs first-tier, supplemental, or second-tier tests shall employ a clinical consultant.
Director as Clinical Consultant. The director may function as the clinical consultant if the director meets the qualifications set forth under §C of this regulation.
Clinical Consultant Qualifications. The clinical consultant shall be:
A doctor of medicine or a doctor of osteopathy licensed to practice medicine or osteopathy; and
Board certified by the American Board of Medical Genetics as a:
Clinical geneticist;
Medical geneticist; or
Biochemical geneticist.
Clinical Consultant Responsibilities. A clinical consultant shall provide clinical consultation related to:
Inquiries concerning specific newborn screening tests;
Interpretation of specific test results;
Possible diagnostic or supplemental testing; and
Assistance in ensuring that appropriate tests are ordered to meet clinical expectations.

section.heading: General Supervisor Requirement, Qualifications, and Responsibilities.

para.text: General Supervisor Requirement. A permittee that offers to perform or performs first-tier, supplemental, or second-tier tests shall employ a general supervisor.
General Supervisor Qualifications. The general supervisor shall:
Meet the qualifications for a general supervisor set forth at COMAR 10.10.07.06B(1); and
Have at least 6 months experience supervising the operation of applicable test systems, including:
Tandem mass spectrophotometry (MS/MS);
Time-resolved immunofluorometry;
Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) systems; and
Isoelectric focusing and high-performance liquid chromatography.
General Supervisor Responsibilities. A general supervisor shall carry out the responsibilities set forth in 42 CFR §493.1463, including:
Supervising the:
Day-to-day operation of the laboratory; and
Personnel performing tests and reporting test results; and

Being accessible to testing personnel at all times testing is performed to provide on-site, telephonic, or electronic consultation and resolve technical problems in accordance with policies and procedures established and approved by the director and technical supervisor.

Requirement. A permittee that offers to perform or performs first-tier, supplemental, or second-tier tests shall employ sufficient laboratory testing personnel to perform testing in accordance with the requirements of this chapter.
Qualifications. Testing personnel shall meet the qualifications set forth at COMAR 10.10.07.07.
First-Tier Tests; Requirement. The Department’s public health laboratory shall perform first-tier tests on all screening blood-spot specimens collected from a newborn infant.
First-Tier Tests; Testing Limitations.
Only the Department's public health laboratory may screen for the disorders listed in §C of this regulation.
A permittee may perform a supplemental or a second-tier test only when the test is requested by an individual authorized to request a medical laboratory test as provided in COMAR 10.10.06.02.

First-Tier Tests. The Department’s public health laboratory shall perform a first-tier test on a newborn infant to screen for the following hereditary and congenital disorders, which are approved for screening by the Council and the Secretary:
Biotinidase deficiency;
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH);
Hypothyroidism;
Galactosemia, galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency (GALT);
Epimerase Galactosemia, uridine diphosphate-galactose-4-epimerase deficiency (GALE);
Galactokinase Galactosemia, galactokinase deficiency (GALK1);
Sickle cell disease;
Sickle cell disease: S beta-thalessemia;
Sickle C disease: SC disease;
Other hemoglobin variants;
Phenylketonuria (PKU);
Hyperphenylalaninemia (Hyper-PHE);
Biopterin cofactor biosynthesis defects (BIOPT-BS);
Biopterin cofactor regeneration defects (BIOPT-REG);
Tyrosinemia, type I;
Tyrosinemia, type II;
Tyrosinemia, type III;
Homocystinuria;
Hypermethioninemia;
Branched chain ketoaciduria (BCK), also called maple syrup urine disease (MSUD);
Citrullinemia, type I;
Citrullinemia, type II;
Arginosuccinic aciduria;
Argininemia;
Methylmalonic acidemia, mutase deficiency (MMA);
Methylmalonic acidemia, adenosylcobalamin synthesis defects A and B (Cbl A, B);
Methylmalonic acidemia, adenosylcobalamin synthesis defects C and D (Cbl C, D);
Propionic acidemia (PA);
Isovaleric acidemia (IVA);
Glutaric aciduria type I (GA I);
3-Hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG) lysase deficiency;
Isobutryl-CoA dehydrogenase (IBCD) deficiency;
2-Methylbutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (2MBG);
3-Methlycrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency (3MCC);
3-Methlyglutaconyl-CoA hydratase deficiency (3MGA);
2-Methyl-3-hydroxybutyrl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (2M3HBA);
Mitochondrial acetoacetyl-CoA thiolase (3-ketothiolase) deficiency (BKT);
Multiple carboxylase deficiency (MCD);
Malonic acidemia (MAL);
Medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCAD);
Medium chain ketoacyl-CoA thiolase deficiency (MCKAT);
Short chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (SCAD);
Short chain 3-hydroxy acyl Co-A dehydrogenase deficiency (SCHAD);
Very long chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (VLCAD);
3-hydroxy long chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (LCHAD);
Multiple acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MAD) or glutaric acidemia type II deficiency (GA II);
Carnitine/acylcarnitine translocase deficiency (translocase deficiency);
Carnitine palmitoyl transferase type I deficiency (CPT I);
Carnitine palmitoyl transferase type II deficiency (CPT II);
Carnitine uptake disorder;
Trifunctional protein deficiency (TFP);
2,4-dienoyl-CoA reductase deficiency (DE RED);
Cystic fibrosis;
Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID);
Pompe disease;
Fabry disease;
Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA);
Mucopolysaccharidosis type I (MPS I);
Mucopolysaccharidosis type II (MPS II);
X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD); and
Guanidinoacetate Methyltransferase Deficiency (GAMT).
Approved Methods:
A permittee shall use:
A colorimetric method for testing for a biotinidase deficiency, which is the disorder listed at §C(1) of this regulation;
A fluorometric method when testing for galactosemia, which is the disorder listed at §C(4)—(6) of this regulation;
A fluorescent-linked immunoassay method when testing for the hereditary or congenital disorders listed in §C(2) and (3) of this regulation;
Isoelectric focusing followed by high-performance liquid chromatography when testing for sickle cell disease, which is the disorder listed at §C(7)—(10) of this regulation;
Tandem mass-spectrometry when testing for the metabolic disorders listed in §C(11)—(52) of this regulation;
IRT/IRT (immunoreactive trypsinogen/immuno-reactive trypsinogen) when testing for cystic fibrosis, which is the disorder listed in §C(53) of this regulation; and
Real time polymerase chain reaction method when testing for severe combined immunodeficiency, which is listed in §C(54) of this regulation.
A permittee shall have 60 days from the amendment's effective date to comply with any amendment made by the Secretary to §D of this regulation.

section.heading: Screening Test Blood-Spot Specimens — Collection and Test Requisition.

para.text: Blood-Spot Specimen Collection.
A person shall collect a newborn infant’s blood-spot specimen for testing under this chapter by using only the special blood-spot specimen collection test requisition card provided by the Department.
The Department shall provide the special blood-spot specimen collection test requisition card to the:
Individual in charge of a birthing facility or the individual’s designated representative; or
Home birth attendant.

The individual in charge of a birthing facility or the individual’s designated representative, or the home birth attendant shall collect a blood-spot specimen consisting of heel-stick whole blood obtained:
When a newborn infant is 24 to 48 hours old;
On a blood-spot specimen collection test requisition card provided by the Department; and
As set forth in Regulation .14 of this chapter.

Blood-Spot Specimen Collection Test Requisition Card Information. An individual shall record the following information as specified on the Department-supplied blood-spot specimen collection test requisition card:
Newborn infant information, including:
Name;
Date of birth;
Time of birth;
Current weight;
Gender;
Race;
Gestational age;
Birthing facility identification, including the:
Facility name;
Facility street address, city, state, and zip code; and
Newborn infant's medical record or chart number;
Date and time of first feeding;
Type of feeding, such as:
Breast;
Lactose-containing formula; or
Formula containing no lactose;
Transfusion history, including transfusion date and time;
General health status of the newborn infant; and
The total protein and calorie intake for any newborn infant in a neonatal intensive care setting;
Blood-spot specimen information, including:
Date of collection;
Time of collection; and
Initials or other identifier of the individual who collected the blood-spot specimen;
Mother or guardian information, including:
Name;
Street address, city, state, and zip code; and
Telephone number where the mother or guardian may be reached;
Information on the pediatrician or attending physician who will be following the newborn infant, including the physician's:
Name;
Street address, city, state, and zip code; and
Telephone number; and
Other information that can affect the test results or the interpretation of the test results when applicable, such as that antibiotics were administered to the:
Mother; or
Newborn infant.

section.heading: Screening Test Blood-Spot Specimens — Procedures, Submission, and Delivery Requirements.

para.text: Standard Operating Procedure. The individual in charge of a birthing facility or the individual’s designated representative, or the home birth attendant shall maintain written standard operating procedures for the collection, handling, storage, and transport of newborn infant blood-spot specimen collection test requisition cards, including instructions for staff to:
Ensure and maintain blood-spot specimen integrity, quality, and acceptability;
Ensure proper:
Site preparation and cleaning;
Performance of the heel stick puncture; and
Application of whole blood to the collection test requisition card;
Identify precautions against:
Milking or squeezing the blood-spot specimen collection site;
Layering successive drops of blood on the same circle on the blood-spot specimen collection test requisition card;
Filling the circles on both sides of the filter paper;
Touching or smearing a blood-spot specimen before it is fully air-dried;
Scratching or abrading the blood-spot specimen;
Not allowing a blood-spot specimen to dry thoroughly before sending the blood-spot specimen collection test requisition card to a laboratory; and
Damaging, stretching, or wrinkling the filter paper before, during or after blood-spot specimen collection;
Recognize unsatisfactory blood-spot specimens; and
Handle and temporarily store a blood-spot specimen collection test requisition card, including the procedures and techniques for:
Drying blood-spot specimens;
Stacking of blood-spot specimen collection test requisition cards; and
Temporarily storing blood-spot specimen collection test requisition cards.

Submission and Delivery Requirements. The individual in charge of a birthing facility or the individual’s designated representative, or the home birth attendant shall transport and deliver to the Department’s public health laboratory a newborn infant blood-spot specimen collection test requisition card using:
An employee or private courier;
A commercial carrier providing:
Overnight express delivery; or
Priority delivery;
A county or State operated courier system, where that service is available; or
A combination of §B(1)—(3) of this regulation.

section.heading: Test Blood-Spot Specimens — Use, Research, Storage, and Retention.

para.text: Use. A permittee may use a newborn infant blood-spot specimen from a newborn infant to test for only the conditions listed in Regulation .12C of this chapter.
Research. A researcher may not use a Maryland newborn infant’s blood spot specimen or test results for research purposes unless the:
Research is approved in writing by the Department's:
Newborn Screening Program; and
Institutional Review Board; and
Researcher acknowledges in writing that the researcher will return all untested blood-spot specimens to the Department’s public health laboratory within 6 months of completing the approved research.
Storage. A permittee or researcher shall store a newborn infant blood-spot specimen in a sealed, moisture-proof container at between 2ºC and 6ºC.
Retention.
A permittee shall:
Retain a newborn infant’s gel, produced when testing for hemoglobin disorders, for at least 90 days after testing is complete; and

Return to the State’s public health laboratory all untested blood-spot specimens received from the Department’s public health laboratory for supplemental or diagnostic testing within 90 days after testing is completed by the permittee.

The Department’s public health laboratory shall retain and maintain for 25 years a newborn infant’s blood-spot specimen after the blood-spot specimen is received for screening, supplemental testing, or diagnostic testing.

section.heading: Test Records — Retention.
section.text: The Department’s public health laboratory shall retain and maintain electronically or as a hard copy for 25 years the:

para.text: Top copy of the requisition portion of the blood-spot specimen collection test requisition card;
All test results and reports;
Electronic data bases; and
Supporting documents that show how a reported test result was obtained and verified, including but not limited to:
Quality control records;
Instrument maintenance and repair records;
Test reagent records; and
Instrument and test system data.

The Department’s public health laboratory shall test, using first-tier tests, appropriately timed and collected blood-spot specimen of a newborn infant’s blood for the disorders listed in Regulation .12C of this chapter.
Full-Term Healthy Newborn Infants.
If a newborn infant is born at term and is healthy, the Department’s public health laboratory shall conduct a:

First screening using first-tier tests to detect the disorders listed in Regulation .12C of this chapter on a blood-spot specimen collected when the full-term healthy newborn infant is between 24 and 48 hours old; and
Second screening using first-tier tests on a blood-spot specimen collected when the full-term healthy infant is between 10 and 14 days old.
If the first blood-spot specimen is collected when a full term healthy newborn infant is younger than 24 hours old, the Department’s public health laboratory shall conduct a:

Second screening using first-tier tests to detect the disorders listed in Regulation .12C of this chapter on a blood-spot specimen collected when the newborn infant is between 24 hours and 7 days old; and
Third screening using first-tier tests on a blood-spot specimen collected when the full-term healthy infant is between 1 and 4 weeks old.
Premature or Ill Newborn Infant.

If a newborn infant who is born prematurely or expected to be ill for more than 14 days was younger than 24 hours old when the blood-spot specimen was collected for a first screening, the Department’s public health laboratory shall conduct a:
Second screening using first-tier tests to detect the disorders listed in Regulation .12C of this chapter when the newborn infant is between 24 hours and 3 days old; and
Third screening using first-tier tests when the newborn infant is between 7 days and 14 days old to screen for:
Amino acid disorders as specified in Regulation .12C(11)—(24) of this chapter;
Acylcarnitine disorders as specified in Regulation .12C(25)—(52) of this chapter;
Congenital hypothyroidism as specified in Regulation .12C(4) of this chapter; and
Severe combined immunodeficiency, as specified in Regulation .12C(54) of this chapter.

If a newborn infant who is born prematurely or expected to be ill for more than 14 days was 24 hours old or older at the time the newborn infant’s blood-spot specimen was collected for a first screening, the Department’s public health laboratory shall perform a second screening to screen for:
Amino acid disorders as specified in Regulation .12C(11)—(24) of this chapter;
Acylcarnitine disorders as specified in Regulation .12C(25)—(52) of this chapter;
Congenital hypothyroidism as specified in Regulation .12C(4) of this chapter; and
Severe combined immunodeficiency, as specified in Regulation .12C(54) of this chapter.

If a newborn infant was transfused before the blood-spot specimen was collected for a first screening, the Department’s public health laboratory shall conduct, in addition to any other screenings specified in §B(1) and (2) of this regulation, a fourth screening using first-tier tests on a blood-spot specimen collected 4 months after a newborn infant’s last transfusion to screen for:
Hemoglobin as specified in Regulation .12C(7)—(10) of this chapter;
Biotinidase as specified in Regulation .12C(1) of this chapter; and
Galactose-1-P-uridyl-1-transferase as specified in Regulation .12C(3) of this chapter.
When a test request is made by an individual authorized to request a laboratory test, as set out in COMAR 10.10.06.02:
A permittee other than the Department's public health laboratory may perform a second-tier or supplemental test; and
The Department's public health laboratory may perform a second-tier test.
A permittee:

May not contract out, subcontract, or otherwise transfer supplemental or second-tier testing to another laboratory that does not hold a Maryland permit in the discipline of diagnostic and supplemental testing for hereditary and congenital disorders in newborns;
Shall complete a second-tier or supplemental test on a blood-spot specimen within 3 working days after the blood-spot specimen arrives at the laboratory; and
Shall report the results of a second-tier or supplemental screening test as required in Regulations .23 and .24 of this chapter.

section.heading: Proficiency and Competency Testing for Newborn Screening Tests.

para.text: Meet all requirements set forth in COMAR 10.10.05;
Successfully participate in one or more approved proficiency testing programs that cover all first-tier, second-tier, and supplementary tests offered or performed;
Evaluate and document performance, semiannually during the first year of testing and annually thereafter, of all individuals responsible for testing; and
In addition to the proficiency testing requirement in §A of this regulation, participate in the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Newborn Screening Quality Assurance Program.
Quality Control Program.

A permittee shall develop, establish, implement, maintain and follow written quality control policies, procedures, and techniques that provide and ensure accurate, reliable, and valid test results and reports.
A permittee's quality control program shall:
Cover all tests, methods, and procedures performed by the laboratory; and
Meet the standards and requirements set forth in this chapter and COMAR 10.10.06.
A permittee's quality control procedures and practices shall include, but are not limited to, the use of:
Analyses of reference materials to ensure the reproducibility and accuracy of test results;
Systems to ensure proper functioning of instruments, equipment, reagents, and performance of laboratory personnel;
Valid reagents, equipment, calibration, and systematic procedural checks;
A system that ensures timely and pertinent error detection and correction for the review and reporting of test results; and
Quality control materials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Newborn Screening Quality Assurance Program.
Adequacy of Methods and Equipment. To ensure the adequacy of test methods, test systems, and equipment, a permittee shall:
Employ methods, test systems, and equipment that provide accurate and reliable test results and reports;
Have sufficient and suitable equipment and instruments to perform the type and volume of tests offered and performed by the laboratory;
Perform tests in a manner that provides accurate and reliable test results;
Monitor test methods, instruments, and testing systems, where applicable, for the following performance characteristics:
Method, instrument, and test system detection limits and cutoff levels;
Precision;
Accuracy;
Specificity;
Sensitivity;
Interferences; and
Other related test variables that affect test results; and
Have adequate quality control systems and procedures in place to:
Obtain and verify a statistically valid number of counts or measurement levels to give accurate and reliable test results for an analytical instrument, each day an instrument is used for testing; and
Report results:
As set forth in COMAR 10.10.06.04;
As set forth in 42 CFR §493.1291; and
Within the time frames required by this chapter.
Supplies, Reagents, and Materials.

A permittee shall ensure that supplies, reagents, and other materials used in the collected, handling, testing, and storing of newborn blood-spot specimens are stored, labeled, checked for proper reactivity, and used according to the provisions of this chapter.
A permittee shall:
Label laboratory supplies and materials used in the testing process, including reagents, solutions, controls, and calibrators to indicate the:
Identity of reagents, solutions, controls, and calibrators;
Strength or concentration;
Storage requirements;
Preparation and expiration date;
Identity of the preparer; and
Other pertinent information that affects test performance;
Store laboratory materials in the manner recommended by the manufacturer;

Test representative samples of each lot of materials used for or in the process of testing blood-spot specimens on a regularly scheduled basis to determine that each lot of test material is capable of performing as required; and
Use supplies, reagents, kits, test systems, and other materials in a manner consistent with the recommendations and instructions provided by the manufacturer.
A permittee may not use supplies, reagents, kits, test systems, or other materials in the testing process that have:
Exceeded the materials' established expiration dates;
Substandard reactivity; or
Deteriorated.
A permittee shall:
Establish and follow a written quality assessment plan that covers all phases of the testing process;
Meet the applicable quality assurance requirements of COMAR 10.10.06; and
Have an accessioning mechanism or system that:
Tracks blood-spot specimens and allows first and subsequent blood-spot specimens and test results from the same newborn infant to be linked for testing and analysis; and
Identifies a specific analyte that requires retesting when a newborn infant's prior screening test results for that analyte are abnormal or border-line abnormal.
A permittee may not test a blood-spot specimen exhibiting:
Blood that did not saturate the filter paper;
A circle containing no blood;
A blood clot or tissue on the surface of the blood;
A circle over-saturated with blood showing dark areas in the circle or at the perimeter;
Blood that appears layered or clotted; or
Serum rings or blood that appears diluted, discolored, or contaminated.
A permittee may not test a blood-spot specimen:
Collected more than 10 days before the screening test is to be started;
That is unaccompanied by information necessary for the testing to be meaningful, including the:
Age of the newborn infant;
Identification of the newborn infant;
Date and time of blood-spot specimen collection;
Date and time of birth;
Newborn infant's weight; and
Date and time of a newborn infant's first feeding;
If an infant was transfused before the first screening and the repeat blood-spot specimen collected to test for hemoglobin was drawn earlier than 4 months after the last transfusion; or
If the newborn infant was younger than 24 hours old or the newborn's age was unknown at the time of collection and the requested screening test is for:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia as specified in Regulation .12C(2) of this chapter; or
Thyroxine or thyroid stimulating hormone as specified in Regulation .12C(4) of this chapter.
Within 24 hours of receipt of an unsatisfactory blood-spot specimen, the permittee shall notify the submitter of the unsatisfactory blood-spot specimen by telephone, facsimile, or electronic mail:
That the blood-spot specimen cannot be tested; and
To submit another blood-spot specimen as soon as possible.
If a permittee reports a test result on a newborn infant and later discovers that the test result was erroneous or questionable, the permittee shall:
Give prompt notice of the erroneous or questionable patient test result to the:
Person who requested that the test be performed;
Physician or other person to whom the laboratory has previously sent a report that contained the erroneous or questionable result; and
Follow-Up Unit;
Provide corrected reports to the persons notified in §E of this regulation;
Maintain duplicates of both the original report and the corrected report;
Conduct a quality assessment of all phases of the testing process to determine the cause of the erroneous or questionable test result;
Take the necessary remedial or corrective action to prevent recurrence of the problem; and
Take any additional measures necessary to reduce or eliminate the threat to the health and safety of the patient including:
Notifying a parent or guardian of the newborn infant of the erroneous or questionable result;
Retesting the same blood-spot specimen;
Testing a new blood-spot specimen; and
Retesting the same blood-spot specimen and testing a new blood-spot specimen.

section.heading: Quality Assurance — Continuity of Operations and Disaster Recovery Plan.
section.text: A permittee shall develop, implement, and maintain written continuity of operations and disaster recovery plans that ensure the continuous performance of essential functions and operations:

para.text: During an emergency; or
When the laboratory temporarily can no longer meet the requirements and standards set forth in this chapter.
All Test Results. For a newborn infant, a permittee shall:
Report all first-tier, supplemental, and second-tier results to:
The person who requested the test; and
An individual who will use the test results in identifying, tracking, caring for, and treating the newborn infant, including:
A physician specialist; and
Personnel in the Follow-Up Unit;
Report to the persons listed in §A(1) of this regulation within 3 working days after the laboratory obtains the blood-spot specimen, all test results that are within normal limits;
Report to a person requesting a second or subsequent screening the test results from the newborn infant's prior screening if not previously reported to the person;
Include with each report the following information:
Date the blood-spot specimen was received in the laboratory;
Date of the report; and
Cut-off level for each reported analyte; and
Report all abnormal test results to the Follow-Up Unit on the same day that a test result is obtained and reviewed.
Specific Test results. A permittee may not report a test result as being within normal limits for:
Amino acid levels for disorders specified in Regulation .12C(11)—(24) of this chapter and for a total galactose level for galactosemia as specified in Regulation .12C(3) of this chapter if:
A newborn infant was not on milk or formula feeding at least 24 hours before the blood-spot specimen was collected; or
The time of milk or formula feeding is unknown; or

17-hydroxy progesterone results for congenital adrenal hyperplasia as specified in Regulation .12C(2) of this chapter and thyroxine and thyroid stimulating hormone for hypothyroidism as specified in Regulation .12C(4) of this chapter if the blood-spot specimen was collected when the newborn infant was:
Younger than 24 hours old; or
Of unknown age.

section.heading: Reporting Abnormal Test Results to the Follow-Up Unit.

para.text: Reporting Requirements. A permittee shall immediately report an abnormal or diagnostic test result to the Follow-Up Unit by:
Telephoning and personally speaking to an individual in the Follow-Up Unit;
Telephoning and personally speaking to a back-up individual representing the Follow-Up Unit, if an attempt to make in-person contact with an employee of the Follow-Up Unit fails; and
Following up a telephonic report within 24 hours with a report by facsimile or electronic mail to the Follow-Up Unit.

Verification Requirement. A permittee shall contact the Follow-Up Unit by telephone at least once every 6 months to ensure that the permittee is able to meet the requirements in §A of this regulation.
Reporting Requirements; General. A permittee shall provide with each abnormal result, where applicable, the:
Identity or name of each analyte measured;
Measured numerical concentration or range of:
Each analyte measured; and
All related analytes measured;
Value of any relevant ratios used to determine abnormality;
Postnatal age of the newborn infant;
Appropriate gestational age/birth weight control range;
Cut-off level for the analyte of a hereditary or congenital disorder; and
Measure of the degree of abnormality of the test result.

Reporting Requirements; Sickle Cell Disease Hemoglobin. A permittee shall report results for hemoglobin disorders as specified in Regulation .12C(7)—(10) of this chapter for sickle cell disease in terminology that includes:
The alleles present in decreasing quantitative order; and
Specifying trait states and possible disease states for at least the following alleles:
Hemoglobin C;
Hemoglobin D;
Hemoglobin E;
Hemoglobin G;
Hemoglobin O; and
Hemoglobin S.

Have available and use a reliable and accurate electronic information system that is capable of collecting, compiling, transferring, and communicating all normal and abnormal test results to the Follow-Up Unit; and
Provide the Follow-Up Unit, where applicable, with:

The necessary information system and electronic communications software or interface to be used by the Follow-Up Unit to receive from the permittee the newborn screening test results and reports required in this chapter; and
Software programming assistance to ensure that the:
Permittee's data transmitted to the Follow-Up Unit is accurate and timely; and
The Follow-Up Unit's information system maintains compatibility with the permittee's information system.

section.heading: Availability of Statistical and Scientific Data.

para.text: Statistical Reports. The State’s public health laboratory, the Follow-Up Unit, or both, on request, shall provide Newborn Screening Program statistical data for official State and national reports to:
The Council;
The Department's Office of Genetics and Children with Special Healthcare Needs; and
State and federal agencies that use test results and statistics for the care and treatment of newborn infants.
Research Investigations. The Laboratories Administration, the Follow-Up Unit, or both, may participate in research investigations approved by the Department's Institutional Review Board.

Due to the life-threatening nature and effect of errors in newborn screening testing, the Secretary may order summarily the suspension of a permit if the Secretary finds that the public health, safety, or welfare imperatively requires emergency action, including but not limited to, if a permittee has:
Failed to report a newborn infant's abnormal test result as required in this chapter;
Falsified a document submitted to the Department, including but not limited to a:
Newborn infant screening test report; or
Quality control or quality assurance report; or
Failed to provide a corrected or amended test report if the permittee has reported an erroneous or questionable test result.
If the Secretary summarily suspends a permit as provided in §A of this regulation, the Secretary shall promptly give the permittee:
Written notice of the suspension, the finding, and the reasons that support the finding; and
An opportunity to be heard.
The Secretary may impose a directed plan of correction, limit testing, deny a permit renewal, or suspend or revoke a current permit if a permittee has:
Failed to meet the applicable standards and requirements set forth in:
Health-General Article, Title 17, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
COMAR 10.10.01—.08 and this chapter;
Conducted research on newborn infant blood-spot specimens within the Newborn Screening Program’s approval as required in Regulation .15 of this chapter; or
Failed to pay the Department any fee required under this subtitle.
In addition to sanctions provided in §§A and C of this regulation, the Secretary may:
Impose any sanction provided in COMAR 10.10.08; and
Refer a person for criminal prosecution, as provided at Health-General Article, §17-216, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A person may have a hearing on the imposition of a sanction and an opportunity to respond to a sanction imposed by the Secretary under this regulation as set forth in COMAR 10.10.08.03.

Except as provided in §§A and B of this regulation, before the Secretary denies, suspends, or revokes a permit, the Secretary shall give the applicant or permittee notice of the action and an opportunity to be heard.
